div.head: Propositio circa generatio caritatis
div.p:
As a declaration of the matter of charity, which affects the whole theological process, as attested by our savior that
from love of God and neighbor depends the entire law and the prophets , one proposition is posited when beginning first from generations which is this: that although the gift of created charity is not absolutely necessary for the pilgrim for reaching salvation, nevertheless according to the established course of the law it is required that this charity concur in three types of causes and in the kingdom of the mind this is principally influxive and essentially required for operating virtuously.

div.head: Rationes pro prima parte
div.p: The first part is proved when understanding that any form united to its subject is united as a mover and as united as act inhering with respect to the disposition of the form to its subject as mover, nevertheless it happens that God is able to supply its causality, for every operation of love reduces to the genus of efficient cause. Whence the Holy Spirit alone suffices to incline the soul to operate meritoriously.

In the second place, the Holy Spirit alone is able to produce the act, which is immediately produced from the mind with mediating charity, therefore with respect to the total causality which charity would have with respect to the soul the Holy Spirit alone would suffice, therefore from the part of the actions the created gift is not necessary since it is able to be supplied through the Holy Spirit.

In the third place, divine acceptance, which is an interior act, is said to be a sufficient cause for this namely that the creature reach salvation, because by the fact that God wills that a creature be worthy of eternal life, it is by that fact worthy. But the will of God does not depend on a created quality, nor does is it co-bound with some quality, since it is sufficient by itself to make a creature worthy. Therefore the Holy Spirit by itself and by its own will is able to accept a creature, and having been so disposed this will be sufficient for the pursuit of salvation.

In the fourth place, before the determination of the church, namely before it would be determined that in baptism three gifts would be infused, namely faith, hope and love, it was not evidently deduced from scripture that there is another charity besides the Holy Spirit. Therefore according to the process of Scripture there appear to be many authorities to the contrary, namely, that no gift is created, indeed there was the Holy Spirit, who operated all meritorious things in creatures, as the
Master states in distinction 17 of book 1
Lombard, Sent. I, d. 17
, which holds expressly this position. From which it appears that from thee power of God absolutely it is possible that the creature is in the state of salvation without the created gift.

div.head: Rationes pro secunda parte
div.p: The second part is proved having two principal parts.

div.head: First part for the second part: that according to the currently established law it is required that some created gifts concurs in three types of causes.
div.p: The first that according to the currently established law it is required that some created gifts concurs in three types of causes, and which is preordained in the kingdom of the mind for the causation of any good work, such that love holds the first place in the kingdom of the mind, such that it is not the case that some good act is produced that charity does not principally concur with respect to that virtuous producible act in the kingdom of the mind.

But in the first place it appears
that some created habit is required through
the Decretalem
positing that in baptism there is infused in children three gifts, faith, hope, and love

In the second place, by the reason in which faith and hope were posited as distinct created gifts, by the same reasons it should be said about charity, because every reason proving about faith and hope could be proved about charity in the same mode.

In the third place, all accidents are posited and ordered into the operations of substances, though perhaps one being reckless would be able to deny accidents, nevertheless these should be conceded for substances and their operation, therefore the soul will have proportional habits and accidents conferring to the execution of its operations, as it appears in natural things from substantial form, which has many accidents, as exercises its proper operations. Therefore with respect to meritoroius operations and acts of loving God and neighbor more noble habits and acts co-acting meritorious works are required.

In the fourth place, in the state of innocence with original justice a distinct virtue is posited rectifying the inferior powers, and it harmonizes these things with the superior powers. Therefore in the state of grace, since this is posited as a supplement to original justice, a distinct thing ought to be posited.

div.head: Secunda pars pro secunda parte
that charity is found in a threefold genus of cause
div.p:
But with respect to the other second part of the second part, namely, that charity is found in threefold genus of cause. In the first place it is proved about the formal cause, not that charity is really informing, but it has itself in the mode of a form, as
Augustine
says this is the
life of virtue , therefore charity has itself in the mode of vivifying form, to which Scripture agrees, saying
faith is dead with works
of charity, and therefore its absence is death. Therefore, charity is like a form vivifying and rectifying the operations of the will.

div.head: That charity is in the genus of material cause.
div.p:
In the second place, Blessed Gregory says
a branch does not have the vigor for good work, unless it remains in the root of charity
Gregory Hom. in Ev., 27
, in this respect that it is to vivify and assist in the pursuit of good work.

There are other authorities asserting approvingly that charity is the form of all virtues, therefore faith without charity is called unformed by all doctors, from which it appears that charity is rightly said to be the form of other virtues and is found in the genus of the material cause.

div.head: That charity is in the genus of the final cause.
div.p: Next, it appears that charity is in the genus of the final cause. This is clear from the priority of the control of the soul because a leader is not the end of the parts of the army, so charity is the end of all the virtues of the soul and that to which the other virtues are ordered in the kingdom of the soul as if subjected to the mode of a superior, in which the other virtues are ordered as the parts of the army are subjected to their prince.

In the second place, with this the
Apostle
agrees, saying, that
the end of the command is love , therefore love is the end of all operations meritorious of eternal life.

div.head: Quod caritas se habeat in genere causae efficientis
div.p: Finally, it is proved that charity is the genus of the efficient cause. This is clear because, just as acts formally generate habits, so habits concur actively in the generation of acts similar to the first acts. In this mode acts generate habits in natural things, and conversely, therefore from charity habits are generated and from these habits are generated acts similar to the first. Consequently, charity concurs actively with respect to meritorious acts.

In the second place, meritorious acts exceed the ability of the natural will, therefore in the same place the concurrence of a supernatural cause is needed, namely of charity, because if it were to concur precisely by assisting in such a way
that it did not help with the achievement of the effect, but were only to assist with the appearance of the soul, then this would seem to be in concord with the error of Pelagius, indeed it would be worse, because Pelagius does deny that charity helps the soul in the execution of its works, nevertheless he concedes that the soul without charity is able to do meritorious work. But if it is posited that charity concurs actively, it follows that it will help the soul with respect to meritorious work, which Pelagius would not have conceded.

Ubi notandum est quod
Augustinus in libro de natura et gratia , qui comparat animam sanitati. Unde notat ibidem quod status innocentiae habuit sanitatem omnium virium in regno animae regimen illarum constituentem. unde superior ratio habuit in anima plenum imperium et singule vires prout oportuit obediebant superiori portioni, sed ratione culpae originalis sublata est iustitia originalis, quae conservabit concordiam inter vires inferiores ad superiorem et loco eius ponitur cupiditas cuius effectus est oppositus et contrarius effectui iustitiae originalis, ita quod officium cupiditatis est trahere portionem superiorem ad obedientiam virium inferiorum. Unde officium portionis superiorum erat contemplari spiritualia et caelestia et per obedientiam ipsius ad vires inferiores trahitur ad vacandum circa terrena nisi per caritatem liberetur.

Ex quo sequitur quod caritas est animae sanitas et agit in anima, ut vires inferiores superiori portioni seu rationi obediant, sed adhuc caritas ultra addit puta roborationem maiorem quam erit sanitas in statu innocentiae.

Ubi notandum est quod in statu innocentiae, anima vi suae sanitatis, licet possit exire in actum dilectionis dei super omnia, non tamen in actu dilectionis dei eiusdem speciei cum illo, quia nunc elicitur mediante caritate. unde si unus actus comparetur ad illum, ut fit comparatio in naturalibus, tunc non est difficultas. Sed dicitur quod anima in statu innocentiae non suffecisset elicere actum eiusdem speciei cum illa, qui mediante caritate producitur a voluntate, nec hoc sufficeret in statu naturae lapsae.

div.head: First corollary
quod caritas evidenter potest denominari omnes species virtutis
div.p:
Ex quo sequitur primo quod caritas evidenter potest denominari omnis species virtutis, et sic evidenter prudentia, fortitudo, iustitia, temperantia, ita quod causaliter sufficit, ut exeat in actum aequalis perfectionis et maioris quam agerent huiusmodi virtutes. Et illud roboratur ex auctoritate
Augustini in libro De moribus ecclesiae
in quo describit singulas virtutes et ponit caritatem vel amorem pro genere in qualibet diffinitione virtutis, et etiam ponit quod caritas potest in omni actu virtutis modo eminentiori quam virtutes.

div.head: Secundum Corollarium
quod caritas sit realiter cognitio
div.p:
Secundo sequitur quod caritas sit realiter cognitio. Patet quia illa potest immediate in actum prudentiae, modo nullus habitus potest in actum prudentiae nisi sit habitus cognitivus, immo sequitur quod caritas potest vocari prudentia, scientia, et sapientia. Et huic concordat
scriptura in Canonica Iohannis dicentis quod caritas est
unctio docens de omnibus
Ioannis I 2:27
.
Et nedum dirigit affectu, sed intellectum practicum et speculativum, igitur est uncio[?] docens de omnibus.

head.supplied: Quod in habitu caritatis relucet veritas credendorum

div.p:
Tertio, sequitur quod in habitu caritatis relucet veritas credendorum. Patet quia caritas potest in actum cuiuslibet veritatis, igitur illa potest in actum credendorum, et licet ex ordinatione divina caritas numquam exeat in actum se sola quia Deus non ordinavit quod in creatura caritas agat sine concursu Spiritus Sancti, et etiam sine spe et fide,
teste Apostolo
quia
sine fide impossibile est Deo placere Ad Hebraeos 11:6 . Nam quantum est ex parte sui caritas posset exire in actum credendorum, ut dicebatur, quia fides nedum est credendorum cognitio, sed amor.

div.head: Quartum Corollarium
Quod credendorum facilitas ex intensione caritatis habet originem
div.p: Quarto sequitur credendorum facilitas ex intensione caritatis habet originem. Patet quia si caritas sit credendorum relucentia quanto illa est intensior tanto magis facilitat animam.

div.head: Quintum Corollarium
Quod caritas est medicina infirmorum circa fidei difficiles articulos
div.p: quinto sequitur quod caritas est medicina infirmorum circa fidei difficiles articulos, ut si in materia trinitatis, praedestinationis reprobationis, incarnationes et in aliis difficiles articulos anima patiatur scrupulum recurrat anima ad caritatem et cessabit eius infirmitas, quia ipsa est quantum ad hoc suprema medicina.

div.head: Sextum corollarium
Quod simplex persona caritate informata est magis virtuosa quam aliquis philosophus
div.p: Sexto, sequitur quod simplex persona caritate informata est magis virtuosa quam aliquis philosophus. ut Seneca vel Socrates, si caritatem non habuerunt. Patet quia eminentiori modo caritatis est quaelibet virtus in quacumque persona quam aliqua virtus esset in se.

Secundo, ipsa caritas est extensior quantum ad multitudinem quia respectu cuiuscumque obiecti illa potest habere actum meritorium. Sed constat quod nulla virtus sine caritate potest habere actum meritorium. immo potest sequi quod parvulus noviter baptizatus est magis virtuosus quam aliquis philosophus, licet in parvulus sit impeditum ex parte corporum, ut exeant in opera meritoria, licet tamen hoc non tollat virtutum magnitudinem. Patet hoc ex eminentia caritatis supra omnes alias virtutes. In adulto vero noviter baptizato est impeditum ne exeat ad opera meritoria facienda, quia licet habeat modicam caritatem difficultas, tamen provenit ex concupiscentia, quae ipsum inclinat ad oppositum et in illo non plene obediunt vires inferiores superioribus.

div.head: Septimum corollarium
Quod pro quocumque regimine caritas est aptissima dispositio
div.p:
Septimo, sequitur quod pro quocumque regimine caritas est aptissima dispositio. Patet quia pro regimine regni animae ipsa est sufficientissima et continet omnes virtutes refrenativas omni passionum, et est sufficiens ad regnum politiae. Primo quia potest regere regnum animae quo dato in aliqua creatura ipsa est apta ad regimen politicum, et quia caritas non quaerit quae sua sunt et proximi. Ideo ipsa est aptissima ad regimen, quia maxime excludit tyrannidum. Nam tyrannus non regit propter bonum politicum, sed propter bonum
proprium, et ideo caritas est aptissima dispositio ad regimen nedum animae, sed politicarum. Et sic caritas potest applicari ad regimen spirituale et temporale.

div.head: Octavum corollarium
Quod in regimine politico et spirituali debet attendi ad caritatem tam ad consilia quam ad quoscumque alios actus
div.p:
Ex quo octavo sequitur quod in regimen politico et spirituali debet attendi ad caritatem tam ad consilia quam ad quoscumque alios actus.
Patet quia caritas est docens omnem scientiam sufficienter, et repraesentat res secundum debitum ordinem nec Deum repraesentat sic quod omnes in eum tendunt et habent essentialem ordinem.

Et ideo denitus[?] ordo per caritatem obicitur et in consiliis per caritatem apparet quid sit faciendum vel non faciendum. Ex quo apparet quod per caritatem debet regi animae regnum et regnum politicum.

div.head: Nonum corollarium
Quod maxima dispositio cessandi schisma praesens esset habere caritatem et recurrere ad eam
div.p: Nono sequitur quod maxima dispositio cedandi schisma praesens esset habere caritatem et recurrere ad eam, quia ipsa non quaerit quae sua sunt nec est ambitiosa nec tendit ad alienorum subpeditationem.

Et posset inferri quod per prius cedandum est schisma regni animae, secundo in politiciibus[?] debet primo tolli schisma spirituale quam generale quia spirituale seu schisma animae est propinquum et immediatum.

div.head: Decimum corollarium
Quod omnis deliberata actio non producta a caritate sortitur difformitatis aliqualem rationem
div.p: Decimo, sequitur quod omnis deliberata actio non producta a caritate sortitur difformitatis aliqualem rationem. Patet quia ipsa sine caritate praeordinatur inordinate et difformiter et omnis talis actio est peccatum, et si non mortale, saltem veniale.

div.head: Undecimum corollarium
Quod operationes ex caritate procedentes vel nullum generat habitum vel generat habitum per illum voluntatis non existentis in actum sublata caritate
div.p: Undecimo, sequitur quod operationes ex caritate procedentes vel nullum generat habitum vel si aliquem generet per illum voluntatis non exit in actum sublata caritate, ut Sortes nunc diligat Deum et proximum et exeat in actum dilectionis Dei et proximi, tunc dicitur quod huiusmodi actus vel nullum generat habitum vel si generet aliquem, tunc sine caritate Sortis non exiret in actus consimiles primis per illum habitum reservatum quia, si sic, sequeretur quod sublata caritate voluntas posset in consimiles actus actibus habitis, quod est falsum, quia habitus sit generati a caritate derelicti non sufficerent in consimiles actus. Patet quia voluntas non potest nisi cum caritate agere actus consimiles illis ex quibus cum caritate voluntas producebat habitus.

div.head: Duodecimum corollarium
Quod difficultas cognoscendi se esse in caritate non consurgit ex eo quod habitus acquisiti per actus caritativos producunt actus similes primis sublata caritate
div.p:
Duodecimo, sequitur quod difficultas cognoscendi se esse in caritate non consurgit ex eo quod habitus acquisiti per actus caritativos producunt actus similes primis sublata caritate. Unde aliqui imaginantur quod si aliquis feratur in dilectionem Dei et proximi, tunc in ipso producitur actus diligendi Deum et proximum mediante caritate. Et ex isto actu generatur habitus qui potest exire in actu diligendi Deum et proximum sublata caritate, et iste actus est primo similis, licet producatur cum caritate. Modo, dicitur totum contrarium, sed difficultas cognoscendi se esse in caritate consurgit ex parte cupiditatis et malorum habituum caritati
incompossibilium et partim ex ignorantia relationum ad actum. Unde stat bene quod aliquis habeat actum fruibilem vel fruitivum, et tamen nescit se habere illum, nam illum actum reffert ad se, quia non potest habere actum reflexum super actus suos et ex hoc consurgit difficultas cognoscendi se esse in caritate.

div.head: Decimumtertium corollarium
Quod caritas non solum est animae sanatio, sed ultra gradum naturalis causalitatis augmentatio vel elevatio
div.p: Tredecimo, sequitur quod caritas non solum est animae sanatio, sed ultra gradum naturalis causalitatis augmentatio vel elevatio, quia voluntas in statu innocentiae non potest in actum in quem nunc potest iuvante caritate, igitur corollarium verum.

Et proportionaliter in materia fidei, sicut fuerunt posita corollaria de laude fidei, ita posset poni de laude caritatis. Unde imaginatur quod sicut fides est instrumentum libere agentis, scilicet, spiritus, scilicet et conformiter se habet primae veritati, ita caritas est qualitas qua Spiritus Sanctus in creatura producitur actus meritorius et est semper Spiritui Sancto conformis quia impossibile est quod caritas exeat contra legem in actum, vel quod actus mediante ipsa elicitur a voluntate contra legem statutam.

div.head: Obiectio
Quod caritas non erit essentialiter subordinata primae veritati vel Spiritu Sancto
div.p: Sed contra arguitur et ponitur quod deus deacceptet creaturam, staret illam caritatem esse in creatura quae esset in peccato, scilicet, subtracto spiritu sancto, et eius speciali assistentia, quia spiritus sanctus et caritas non simul colligantur, tunc ponatur quod ex caritate voluntas producat actum ille non erit meritorius, sed obliquus. sed et per consequens, caritas non erit essentialiter subordinata primae veritati vel spiritui sancto. illud argumentum fuit factum similiter de fide.
Et ideo respondetur admittendo totum casum. Et dicitur quod, licet illa quantitas quae est caritas remanet, non tamen remaneret in esse caritatis.

Secundo dicitur quod voluntas non exiret in actum quia activitas caritatis est activitas spiritualis praerequirens influxum Spiritus Sancti et influxum esse superioris secum concurrentis modo dicitur quod Spiritus Sanctus non potest agere immediate et specialiter ad mali productionem, igitur nec caritas cum spiritus sanctus semper dirigit caritatem in suis operationibus. Et ideo caritas semper prarequirit superiorem causam concurrentem cum ea et eius causalitas est talis quod semper praerequirit causalitatem Spiritus Sancti. Et sic apparet quod caritas non potest concurrere uniformiter ad malum, sicut ad bonum.
